title: Adding mean, variance, stddev to distributions
body_html:
Behaviors worth mentioning:

  • Cauchy: mean = nan, variance= inf
  • Categorical: mean = nan, variance= nan
  • F: mean = nan for df2 <= 2, variance= nan for df2 <= 4
  • OneHotCategorical(p): behaves like Multinomial(1,p)
  • Pareto: mean = inf for alpha <= 1, variance= inf for alpha <= 2
  • StudentT: mean = nan for df <= 1, variance = inf for 1 <df <= 2, variance = nan for df <= 1

cc. @apaszke
body_text:
Behaviors worth mentioning:

Cauchy: mean = nan, variance= inf
Categorical: mean = nan, variance= nan
F: mean = nan for df2 <= 2, variance= nan for df2 <= 4
OneHotCategorical(p): behaves like Multinomial(1,p)
Pareto: mean = inf for alpha <= 1, variance= inf for alpha <= 2
StudentT: mean = nan for df <= 1, variance = inf for 1 <df <= 2, variance = nan for df <= 1

cc. @apaszke
body:
Behaviors worth mentioning:
- `Cauchy`: `mean` = `nan`, `variance`= `inf`
- `Categorical`: `mean` = `nan`, `variance`= `nan`
- `F`: `mean` = `nan` for `df2` <= 2, `variance`= `nan` for `df2` <= 4
- `OneHotCategorical(p)`: behaves like `Multinomial(1,p)`
- `Pareto`: `mean` = `inf` for `alpha` <= 1, `variance`= `inf` for `alpha` <= 2
- `StudentT`: `mean` = `nan` for `df` <= 1, `variance` = `inf` for 1 <`df` <= 2, `variance` = `nan` for `df` <= 1  

cc. @apaszke
